div.p: The diffusion of the halogens fluorine, chlorine and bromine was measured in a hawaiitic melt from Mt. Etna at 500 MPa and 1.0 GPa, 1250 to 1450 °C at anhydrous conditions; the diffusion of F and Cl in the melt was also studied with about 3 wt% of dissolved water. Experiments were performed using the diffusion-couple technique in a piston cylinder. Most experiments were performed with only one halogen diffusing between the halogen-enriched and halogen-poor halves of the diffusion couple, but a few experiments with a mixture of halogens (F, Cl and Br) were also performed in order to investigate the possibility of interactions between the halogens during diffusion. Fluorine and chlorine diffusivity show a very similar behavior, slightly diverging at low temperature. Bromine diffusion is a factor of about 2-5 lower than the other halogens in this study. Diffusion coefficients for fluorine range between 2.3 • 10 À11 and 1.4 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 , for chlorine between 1.1 • 10 À11 and 1.3 • 10 À10 and for bromine between 9.4 • 10 À12 and 6.8 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 . No pressure effect was detected at the conditions investigated. In experiments involving mixed halogens, the diffusivities appear to decrease slightly (by a factor of $3), and are more uniform among the three elements. However, activation energies for diffusion do not appear to differ between experiments with individual halogens or when they are all mixed together. The effect of water increases the diffusion coefficients of F and Cl by no more than a factor of 3 compared to the anhydrous melt (D F = 4.0 • 10 À11 to 1.6 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 ; D Cl = 3.0 • 10 À11 to 1.9 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 ). Comparing our results to the diffusion coefficients of other volatiles in nominally dry basaltic melts, halogen diffusivities are about one order of magnitude lower than H 2 O, similar to CO 2 , and a factor of $5 higher than S. The contrasting volatile diffusivities may affect the variable extent of volatile degassing upon melt depressurization and vesiculation, and can help our understanding of the compositions of rapidly grown magmatic bubbles.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Each year millions of tons of volatiles are released into the atmosphere by volcanic activity either by active or passive degassing (Halmer et al., 2002). One volcano in particular, Mt. Etna (Italy) is characterized by large gas emission rates (Allard et al., 1991) and high volatile concentrations in the magma compared to other active volcanoes (Me ´trich et al., 2004).

Although the most abundant volatiles in magmas are H 2 O, CO 2 and SO 2 (Symonds et al., 1994), the halogens, F, Cl and Br, play an important role in magmatic systems. Changes in the ratios of halogens to other gases may be potential precursors of explosive volcanic activity such as changes in the ratios of SO 2 /HCl, SO 2 /HF and BrO/SO 2 measured before eruptions (Bobrowski et al., 2003;Aiuppa and Federico, 2004). Halogens also affect melt physical properties (e.g., Wyllie and Tuttle, 1961;Dingwell and Mysen, 1985;Lange, 1994;Giordano et al., 2004), and phase equilibria (e.g., Manning, 1981;Dolejs and Baker, 2004). Additionally, degassed halogens act as transport agents by forming complexes with metals in hydrothermal fluids (Boudreau et al., 1986). Volcanic emissions of halogens to the atmosphere can have a significant impact on Earth's climate and environment (Aiuppa et al., 2001;Bobrowski et al., 2003).

Most studies designed to investigate the behavior of volatiles in silicate melts concentrated on H 2 O and CO 2 , mainly in silicic and intermediate compositions (e.g., Fogel and Rutherford, 1990;Nowak and Behrens, 1997;Zhang and Behrens, 2000;Tamic et al., 2001;King and Holloway, 2002;Mysen and Cody, 2004); only a few studied other melt compositions (Zhang and Stolper, 1991;Carroll and Blank, 1997;Pineau et al., 1998;Morizet et al., 2002;Freda et al., 2003). Even sulfur, the third most abundant volatile in silicate melts, has only been investigated in a few studies of solubility (e.g., Carroll and Rutherford, 1988;Wallace and Carmichael, 1992;Carroll and Webster, 1994;Scaillet and Pichavant, 2003;Botcharnikov et al., 2004) and diffusivity (Watson et al., 1993;Baker and Rutherford, 1996;Winther et al., 1998;Freda et al., 2005). Fewer studies are available on halogens in silicate melts, and we are still far from a comprehensive understanding of their properties. The most investigated halogen is chlorine (e.g., Watson, 1991;Me ´trich and Rutherford, 1992;Bai and Koster van Groos, 1994;Webster et al., 1999;Signorelli andCarroll, 2000, 2002;Webster and De Vivo, 2002;Botcharnikov et al., 2004), followed by fluorine (e.g., Dingwell andScarfe, 1984, 1985) then bromine and iodine (Bureau et al., 2000;Bureau and Metrich, 2003). Despite the increasing use of halogens in volcanic plumes to forecast eruptions and the role of volatile diffusion to growing bubbles as a crucial process during vesiculation, no measurements have been made on halogen diffusivity in basaltic melts.

To improve our knowledge of volatile diffusion, we performed experiments to measure the diffusion coefficients of fluorine, chlorine and bromine in a basaltic melt from Mt. Etna under different conditions of pressure and temperature. Although diffusion itself cannot explain large scale transport properties, this process represents a fundamental mechanism in the modeling of halogen behavior in melts and consequently their degassing.

div.head: EXPERIMENTAL AND ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUES
div.p: The powdered starting material was a hawaiitic, glassy alkaline basalt (Table 1) with Mg# = 59, sampled from the 18th of July 2001 eruption of Mount Etna (Italy), and already used by Freda et al. (2005) for measurements of sulfur diffusivity. Once the sample was crushed and ground, we fused it in a graphite crucible at 1400 °C to remove H 2 O and CO 2 naturally present. We then fused an aliquot at 1.0 GPa, 1400 °C for 2 h in a graphite capsule inside a pyrophyllite cup in a piston-cylinder apparatus, using a 1.91 cm NaCl-crushable alumina-pyrex glass assembly (Freda et al., 2003) to produce a glass containing only negligible amounts of volatiles. In order to make our F-, Cl-, or Br-enriched starting materials we added these halogens as salts. We added approximately 4000 ppm of NaCl to one aliquot of the glass, approximately 4200 ppm of NaF to an-other and about 6300 ppm of NaBr to a third one. The fourth aliquot contained basalt plus a mixture of NaCl + NaF + NaBr (respectively: 9200 ppm, 10900 ppm, 6500 ppm). After grinding each mixture under ethanol in an agate mortar for 30 min they were dried at 400 °C for 3 h. Then, each mixture was fused at 1400 °C, 1.0 GPa for 2 h in piston-cylinder apparatus using the same assembly as above. In order to obtain hydrous glasses, we added about 3 wt% distilled water to aliquots of the dry glasses and fused them in graphite capsules inside welded Pt tubes at 1250 °C and 1.0 GPa for 2 h. In this case a thin layer of pyrophyllite powder surrounded the platinum capsules to avoid water loss.

The diffusion couple was constructed by first drilling two cylindrical holes (2 mm diameter, 4.5 mm long) in a graphite cylinder. The halogen-poor basalt glass powder was packed into the lower halves of both holes and the top halves were filled with the halogen-spiked basalt glasses (either NaCl, NaF, NaBr, or NaCl + NaF + NaBr). In early experiments we sprinkled a few micrograms of platinum powder to mark the interface between the melts to investigate possible convection during the experiments, but found this procedure unnecessary and abandoned it. The top of each hole was sealed with a graphite plug. The same type of assembly as used for preparing the starting glasses was employed in all the dry diffusion couple experiments. All loaded assemblies were stored at 110 °C for 1.5 h before the experiment. To perform the hydrated diffusion experiments we used graphite capsules (1 mm inner diameter and 4.5 long) inside welded platinum capsules in a NaCl-crushable alumina assembly (Freda et al., 2001).

The experimental temperatures range between 1250 and 1450 °C at 1.0 GPa; we also performed a single experiment at 1250 °C, 0.5 GPa to investigate the effect of pressure on diffusion (Table 2) at mid-crustal to lower crustal depths. The run procedure consisted of simultaneously pressurizing a Average of multiple analyses of the glass with the electron microprobe. The number of analysis points is given in parentheses.

c Fluorine detection limit: $300 ppm.

and heating the assembly. A constant heating rate of 100 °C/min was used which resulted in less than a 5 °C overshoot of the run temperature. Temperatures were measured with Type C thermocouples. Pressure calibration for the NaCl-graphite in pyrophyllite cup-crushable aluminapyrex assemblies established that the nominal pressure is within 25 MPa of the actual pressure, whereas the NaClcrushable alumina-pyrex assembly has a pressure 50 MPa above the nominal pressure as based on our previous calibration; the pressure correction is included in all recorded pressures.

All experimental durations (between 300 and 1800 s, Tables 2 and3) are based upon the time at which the experiment reached the desired run temperature. Two ''zerotime'' experiments were performed in order to investigate the extent of diffusion during heating to the experimental temperatures of 1400 and 1450 °C; these experiments pro-duced profiles of up to 300 microns in length, presumably due to either diffusion during heating or a small amount of mixing between the halogen-bearing and halogen-free powders during capsule loading. Although this artifact could potentially affect our results, our repeat experiments of different durations demonstrated that the measured diffusion coefficients were insensitive to run duration. Therefore these profiles present at the start of the experiments did not affect our results. A few runs were performed at identical temperatures, but of different duration to verify if diffusion was the only transport process during the experiments. At the end of each experiment the samples were quenched at 2000 °C/min; hydrous experiments were quenched isobarically.

After quenching, the samples were mounted in epoxy, sectioned longitudinally and polished for analysis of the halogen diffusion profiles using the electron microprobe. All anhydrous experiments were performed in graphite capsules 2 mm internal diameter, 4.5 mm long in pyrophyllite cups in NaCl-pyrexcrushable alumina assemblies.

We used a 15 kV accelerating voltage, a 20 nA current and a 10 lm diameter beam. Major elements were counted for 20 s on the X-ray peaks and 10 s on the background, while chlorine was counted for 60 s on the peak and 30 s on the background, and fluorine was counted for 200 s on the peak and 100 s on the background. Standards for the major elements were natural basaltic glasses; vanadinite was used as the chlorine standard and fluorite as the fluorine standard.

The chlorine minimum detection limit was about 130 ppm, whereas the one for fluorine was approximately 300 ppm. These analytical techniques were checked against a standard glass (KE12) containing 0.33 wt% Cl and 0.42 wt% F and reproduce the certified values to within 10 relative percent. The good totals from the microprobe analysis of anhydrous runs (100 ± 1%) encouraged us to use the ''difference from 100 technique'' (Devine et al., 1995) on the hydrous experiments to estimate the water concentration. These estimated water concentrations are constant throughout each hydrous experiment and average 3 ± 0.75 wt%.

In order to measure bromine diffusion at natural concentrations (100's of ppm), we used the SYXRF microprobe, ID18F, at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF), France because of its low detection limit. A double crystal monochromator using Si (1 1 1) crystals was set to produce a beam of 14.4 keV X-ray excitation energy and the secondary X-rays detected by a Si(Li) detector (Somogyi et al., 2001); we used a 2.5 • 8 lm beam and 100 s counting time for each point. A standard was previously prepared by adding 6500 ppm of NaBr to the Etna basalt and fusing it using the techniques discussed above. This standard allowed us to calculate the Br concentration directly from the intensity of the Br peaks in the Br diffusion couple.

div.head: Calculation of halogen diffusion from concentration profiles
div.p: Fluorine, chlorine and bromine concentrations were plotted in concentration vs. distance diagrams (Fig. 1), and we calculated the diffusion coefficient for each species (Table 2). The concentration profiles of fluorine, chlorine and bromine were used with the following expression which assumes a constant diffusivity between semi-infinite media (Crank, 1975):

div.p: where C(x, t) is the concentration along the diffusion profile at distance x, t is the experimental time, C 1 is the concentration in the depleted semi-infinite medium, C 2 is the concentration in the enriched medium, x 0 is the position of the interface between the two melts along the diffusion profile; D is the diffusion coefficient. This procedure allowed us to derive both the interface and the diffusion coefficient by a non-linear, least squares fit of Eq. ( 1) to the profile. Halogen diffusion profiles were typically 10 3 microns long. The''zero-time'' experiments at 1400 and 1450 °C produced profiles only about 300 lm long, which demonstrated that no significant chemical diffusion took place during the heating. The good fits of the theoretical diffusion equation with our data confirm the assumption that diffusion is independent of halogen concentration.

Analytical uncertainties in our measured diffusion coefficients were determined using a Monte Carlo technique. This technique began by choosing a random fraction of the uncertainty associated with a halogen concentration in a diffusion profile; to this value was randomly assigned a positive or negative sign and added to the measured halogen concentration. After repeating this procedure for each analysis in the measured profile, a surrogate profile was created and the diffusion coefficient was determined following the same non-linear, least squares method used for the experimental profile. Repeating this procedure ten times for profiles yielding the highest and the lowest diffusion coefficients demonstrated that the uncertainty in our measured diffusion coefficient from a single experiment is less than 10 relative percent. In order to investigate inter-experimental reproducibility we performed four pairs of diffusion experiments, the only difference within each pair being the duration. A necessary condition for the good quality of our results is that diffusion is the only transport mechanism during the experiments. Convection, indeed, might compromise the resulting figures in low viscosity melts, such as basaltic ones. In order to check for convection, we sprinkled in some capsules few micrograms of Pt powder at the interface of the diffusion couple to observe if the very thin layer changed after the experiments. We found no evidence of convection and good agreement between the calculated interface of the diffusion couple and the Pt marker after the runs. For the same purpose we also repeated a few runs (1400 and 1450 °C) for different durations and measured replicate traverses in the diffusion couples. Both the resulting profiles of replicate experiments and duplicate traverses produced similar diffusion coefficients (Table 2). Moreover, compositional maps made using the SYXRF microscope of two runs at 1250 and 1450 °C showed no anomalies in diffusion along the profile. All these tests demonstrated that diffusion was the only transport process occurring in our experiments.

div.head: Effect of temperature, water content, pressure and mixed halogen on diffusion
div.p: Diffusion measurements were made at temperatures from 1250 to 1450 °C. Diffusion coefficients for fluorine in anhydrous melts at 1.0 GPa range from 2.3 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 at 1250 °C to 1.4 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 at 1450 °C, whereas the chlorine diffusivities range between 1.1 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 and 1.3 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 and bromine ones between 9.4 • 10 À12 and 6.8 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 . The diffusion coefficients of F and Cl measured in the basalts containing $3 wt% H 2 O vary from 4.0 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 at 1250 °C to 1.6 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 at 1400 °C for F, whereas for the chlorine the minimum value is 3.0 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 and the maximum is 1.9 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 .
Fluorine, chlorine and bromine diffusion display Arrhenian behavior (Fig. 2a, b andc, respectively) that follows the general equation:

div.p: where D is the diffusion coefficient in m 2 s À1 , D 0 is the preexponential factor, E a is the activation energy in kJ mol À1 , R (J K À1 mol À1 ) is the gas constant and T the temperature in K.
The Arrehenius equations describing halogen diffusion at anhydrous and hydrous conditions are presented in Table 4.

We performed experiments at 0.5 GPa and 1250 °C (Table 2) to check for possible pressure effects on fluorine and chlorine diffusion; the diffusion coefficients of 2.6 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 for F and 1.9 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 for Cl are comparable with the measurements at the same temperature and 1.0 GPa indicating that pressure does not exert a significant affect on diffusion of fluorine and chlorine at pressures between 0.5 and 1.0 GPa. Although the measurements for both F and Cl at 0.5 and 1.0 GPa are within inter-experimental reproducibility, the F diffusivity decreases by a factor of 1.1 and Cl decreases by a factor of 1.7 over this pressure range. The ratio of these two possible pressure effects, 1.5, roughly correlates with the ratio of the Cl to F ionic radii, 1.4. If this correlation between ionic radii and the relative effect of pressure on the diffusion holds true, we would expect that the difference in Br diffusion coefficients at 0.5 and 1.0 GPa would be approximately the ratio of the Br to Cl ionic radii, 2.0.

It is well known from glass science that transport processes are affected by the mixed alkali effect, which refers to the large changes in many glass properties when a second alkali oxide is added to an alkali-bearing glass (Day, 1976). We were curious as to whether or not there might exist a similar effect with the halogens. Therefore, we performed one set of experiments from 1250 to 1450 °C at 1.0 GPa containing a halogen mixture of fluorine, chlorine and bromine in order to check for a possible mixed halogen effect on diffusivity. When all three volatiles diffuse together the fluorine diffusivity ranges between 2.5 • 10 À11 and 1.1 • 10 À10 m 2 s À1 , the chlorine between 1.4 • 10 À11 and 7.3 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 , and the bromine between 1 • 10 À11 and 5.3 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 (Fig. 2). In the range of temperature investigated we cannot clearly assess if the diffusivities of fluorine, chlorine and bromine are affected by the presence of other halogens in the melt. Indeed, the slight differences in diffusivity at the lower temperatures (1250-1300 °C, Table 2) are just within the uncertainty of the measurements. If there is a mixed halogen effect it is probably not important in natural basaltic melt compositions.

div.head: Influence of ionic size on the diffusion of halogens
div.p: Since the classic measurements of diffusion in igneous melt compositions in the 1960s and 1970s it has been appreciated that tracer diffusion of elements is a function of both their charge and their radius (Winchell and Norman, 1969;Magaritz and Hofmann, 1978a,b and cited references therein; Jambon and Semet, 1978). The effect of radius on the diffusion of ions and noble gases in basaltic melts at 1350 °C is shown in Fig. 3. Noble gases (He, Ne, Ar, Xe and Kr) and alkali cations (Li, Na and Cs) show a noticeable negative correlation between D and the radius, while diffusivities of 2 + (Co, Mn, Sr and Ba), 3 + (Fe, Sc and Eu), 1 À (F, Cl and Br) and 2 À (O and S) ions are, at most, weakly influenced by ionic radius. Lux (1987) found that noble gas diffusivity follows a linear, monotonic decrease with increasing atomic radius. This strong dependence on radius was interpreted to indicate the dominant control of atomic radius on diffusion and the movement of noble gases through the free volume (''vacancies'') in the melt, as characterized by the ionic porosity (cf. Carroll and Stolper, 1991). The similarly strong dependence of alkali diffusivity on ionic radius is also interpreted to indicate that movement of these cations is driven by diffusion through the free volume in the melt (Henderson et al., 1985). On the other hand, the weak dependence of the diffusion of divalent and trivalent cations on ionic radius led Henderson et al. (1985) to suggest that their diffusion is dominantly controlled by exchange mechanisms that preserve local charge balance.

In sharp contrast to the diffusion behavior of monovalent cations and noble gases, halogen diffusion coefficients are almost insensitive to ionic radius (Fig. 3). This behavior indicates that despite the similarity of the halogen ionic radii to the noble gas atomic radii, the diffusion mechanism is not one involving movement through the free volume of the melt, but instead is dominated by exchange mechanisms. This interpretation is supported by the similarity of the activation energies for halogen diffusion with those of divalent and trivalent cations (cf. Henderson et al., 1985). The exchange mechanism is probably the replacement of oxygen by halogens in the melt (cf. Schaller et al., 1992). However, the affect of anion charge appears less than that of cation charge because of the similarities between the diffusion coefficients of 2 À oxygen (Dunn, 1983) and sulfur (Freda et al., 2005) with those of 1 À halogens due to anion exchange during diffusion.

div.head: Halogen diffusion in different melt compositions
div.p: It is well known that diffusivity usually depends on the composition of the medium and so on its structure. Little information is available on fluorine and chlorine diffusion in silicate melts and nothing for bromine diffusion. In Fig. 4 we compare our results in basaltic melt with halogen diffusion data from previous studies on different melt compositions.

The only data available on fluorine diffusivity in petrologically relevant silicate melts are from Dingwell andScarfe (1984, 1985), who studied the chemical diffusion of fluorine as F-O interdiffusion in jadeitic and albitic melts.

Comparison of the 1.0 GPa results of Dingwell and Scarfe (1984) to our results demonstrates that diffusion coefficients in jadeitic melts are very close to those in basaltic melts (Fig. 4). However, Dingwell and Scarfe (1985) observed a 6-fold increase in F diffusivity between 1 atm and 1.0 GPa in jadeitic melt, whereas our measurements on a basaltic melt yield a decrease of only 1.1, which is within our inter-experimental variability. The differing influence of pressure on F diffusion in jadeitic melt and in basaltic melt is possibly due to the difference in experimental techniques used in this study and in Dingwell andScarfe (1984, 1985), where their 1 atm experiments involved the loss of F, Si, Al and Na from the melt by vaporization, potentially creating a much greater chemical potential gradient than in our study. Nevertheless, comparison between our results and those of Dingwell and Scarfe suggests that any pressure affect on F diffusion in basaltic melts between 1 atm and 0.5 GPa will be small. Dingwell and Scarfe's (1985) measurements of F diffusion in albite melt at 1 atm indicate that its diffusivity is about two orders of magnitude lower than in jadeite and in basalt (Fig. 4) at 1.0 GPa, and there is about 1 order of magnitude difference between F diffusion in jadeitic and albitic melts at 1 atm. These differences are most probably due to the differing compositions as discussed by Dingwell and Scarfe (1985).

The first measurements of chlorine tracer diffusion were performed by Watson and Bender (1980) on a simple Na-Ca-Al-Si-O melt at temperatures between 1100 and 1300 °C and pressures from 0.6 to 1.8 GPa. Their results revealed no pressure dependence of Cl diffusion and are quite similar to our results in natural basaltic melts, which change by less than a factor of 2 between 0.5 and 1.0 GPa and are within experimental reproducibility. Watson (1991) investigated Cl tracer diffusion at 1.0 GPa and temperature ranging from 850 to 1100 °C in rhyolitic and in dacitic melts with 8 wt% H 2 O and found that diffusion coefficients for the rhyolitic melt ranges between 1.2 • 10 À11 and 3.2 • 10 À12 m 2 s À1 .

Bai and Koster van Groos (1994) produced a comprehensive study on the diffusivity of chlorine in silicic melts. They measured Cl chemical diffusion in hydrous and anhydrous rhyolitic melts at temperatures between 850 and 1400 °C and pressures between 1 atm and 0.46 GPa. Their results show that the diffusion of chlorine in both the anhydrous and hydrous melts follows an Arrhenian law. They also demonstrated that increasing pressure from 0.2 to 0.46 GPa at 850 °C results in a small decrease of D Cl , by approximately a factor of 2, unlike our results where we have not measured a pressure effect. A compositional effect is most probably the cause of the rapid increase of D Cl in the presence of 2-3 wt% H 2 O in the silicic melt compared to the small effect recorded in the basaltic melt of our study.

div.head: Comparison between halogen diffusion and diffusion of other volatiles in basalts
div.p: Very few studies have been performed on the diffusion of volatile elements in basaltic melts, although the importance of understanding volatile behavior in such a common melt composition is great. As shown in Fig. 5, diffusion coefficients for water are generally 1 order of magnitude higher than for halogens and the activation energy is slightly lower than for halogen diffusion in either anhydrous or hydrous basalt. Watson et al. (1982) used an iron-free basalt to investigate CO 2 diffusion from 1350 to 1500 °C at 1.5 GPa. Zhang and Stolper (1991) produced a single measurement of D CO 2 at 1300 °C that agrees with the down-temperature extrapolation of the Watson et al. (1982) data. Carbon dioxide diffusion is slightly slower than halogens but it is worth noting that bromine and CO 2 diffusion tend to converge at higher temperatures.

Sulfur diffusion in basaltic melts has been recently studied by Freda et al. (2005). They performed experiments at temperatures ranging from 1250 to 1450 °C at 1.0 GPa in hydrous and anhydrous melts and found that sulfur diffuses slower than H 2 O and CO 2 in basaltic melts. Compared to halogen diffusion, sulfur diffusion is from 4 to 6 times lower, but the activation energy is comparable with that of halogens at anhydrous conditions.

The comparison between halogen and noble gas diffusion (Lux, 1987) is displayed in Fig. 3. Noble gases diffuse 1 to 2 orders of magnitude faster than halogens, but the data of Lux (1987) are not sufficient to determine the activation energy and ascertain whether or not this energy is similar to those of the other volatiles in basaltic melts. Although there is a strong dependence of noble gas diffusion on their radii (Fig. 3), surprisingly all noble gases diffuse more rapidly than other volatiles in basaltic melts.

div.head: PETROLOGICAL APPLICATIONS
div.p: The diffusion data measured in this study combined with data from other studies discussed above provide important constraints on the transport of volatiles in basaltic melts. The diffusion of almost all volatiles in basaltic melts during melting, crystallization and assimilation can now be calculated. However, a more interesting application of these measurements, and indeed the impetus for this study, is the investigation of the role of diffusion during magmatic degassing.

In order to investigate the importance of diffusion during bubble growth we constructed an illustrative model of F, Cl, Br and S behavior during the rapid growth of water bubbles in a basaltic melt at 1250 °C (Fig. 6). To simplify the calculations we assumed one dimensional bubble growth occurring at a constant growth rate. The effect of volatile diffusion combined with fluid/melt partition coefficients can be modeled with Eq. ( 27) of Smith et al. (1955); this equation was used to calculate the bubble rim composition at each stage during growth to a size of 100 microns. These individual compositions were integrated to calculate the bulk composition of the bubble at different growth rates, from 10 À10 to 10 À6 m s À1 . To perform these calculations we used the diffusion coefficients of the halogens from this study and their partition coefficients between melt and a hydrous gas phase. Because of the higher diffusivity of water in basaltic melts (Fig. 5) we assumed that the water concentration in the bubble remained constant and dominated its composition, as in nature. The concentration of each volatile was modeled to be 500 ppm at infinite distance from the growing bubble. We used our hydrous diffusion coefficients of F and Cl at 1250 °C, and based upon the effect of water on Cl diffusion estimated the hydrous diffusion coefficient of Br to be 2.7 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 . For the partition coefficient of fluorine we used the maximum value of 2.5 calculated after Aiuppa et al. (2004); for the partition coefficient of Cl we used a value of 8.4 (Alletti et al., 2006), and for the partition coefficient of Br we used 18 (Bureau et al., 2000). Note that the equilibrium concentrations in the bubble shown in the caption are not achieved, even for the slowest growth rates considered. Please see text for further discussion.

we investigated, 2 • 10 À11 m 2 s À1 , and a partition coefficient of 840 (R. Moretti, private communication 2006). A maximum growth size of 100 microns was chosen because studies of bubble growth in nature and in the laboratory indicate that diffusive growth only dominates for bubbles of this size or less (Gaonac'h et al., 1996;Baker et al., 2006). At larger sizes bubble growth occurs by coalescence and for modeling purposes we do not allow the bubbles to later equilibrate with the magma. For each volatile under consideration the concentration calculations terminate at the fastest growth rate where the calculations produce real results (Fig. 6), but we use the approximate power law relationship between the volatile concentration in the bubble and the growth rate to extrapolate the calculations to higher growth rates. The largest growth rate at which the calculations produced real results for sulfur was 10 À11 m s À1 ; the estimated composition of S in the growing bubble shown in Fig. 6 is based upon the sulfur concentration calculated at growth rates of 10 À12 m s À1 , 165 507 ppm S, and 10 À11 m s À1 , 69 243 ppm S. The extrapolations are conservative because the calculated points demonstrate a curvature towards lower concentrations than those predicted by the power laws (Fig. 6).

The model demonstrates that as the growth rate increases from 10 À10 to 10 À6 m s À1 the bubble composition departs significantly from that calculated with the equilibrium partition coefficients (Fig. 6); even at a slow growth rate of 10 À10 m s À1 the composition of the bubbles are not at equilibrium. The extent of departure from equilibrium behavior is a function of both the partition coefficient and the diffusivity, where volatiles with low diffusivity and very high, or very low, partition coefficients will display the greatest deviations. Thus, of the elements considered, sulfur is the volatile most likely to undergo diffusive fractionation during rapid bubble growth. These calculations demonstrate that the ratio of volatile concentrations in the gas phase can change significantly, especially the ratio between sulfur and F that decrease from 23 to 1 in Fig. 6 and will drop below one at even faster growth rates. But, even the ratios of Br/F and Cl/F change significantly from 6 to 1 and 2.5 to 1, respectively, for the growth rates considered.

Although this model cannot be directly applied to volcanic gas emissions, the results point to a very useful prognostic tool that has the potential to aid volcanologists. The model indicates that at steady state degassing conditions the ratios of the volatiles in the gas phase should remain constant. If the bubble growth rate increases and all other intrinsic and extrinsic variables remain constant, the ratios of S/F, Br/F and Cl/F decrease toward 1, with the S/F ratio most influenced and the Cl/F ratio the least. On the contrary, if the bubble growth rate decreases these ratios should increase. The magnitude of the changes in the ratio should correspond to changes in the rate of bubble growth. Although the degassing of volcanic magmas is additionally complicated by changes in the volatile concentrations in the magma, changes in partition coefficients and changes in the pressure at which degassing occurs, this model indicates that a volcanic monitoring program that continuously measures the ratios of all of these volatiles has the potential to predict the threat of an impending eruption.
